weakness in the step they had taken. The Russian Government first accedes to a most important political step and then at the last moment withdraws ite sanction. But instead of putting an absolute veto on the conference it allows the representatives of the Zemstvos to meet in private. The consequences were obvious Radical resolutions are adopted, a Constitution is demanded, together with liberty of conscience, liberty of the Press, liberty of speech, and liberty of education, besides an elective legislative assembly. This private conference was only held on Saturday, but by Monday the facts are known to the world and the ball has been set rolling which, under the leadership of a Slavonic Mirabeau or Lafs- yette, may lead to the ruin of militant auto- eracy throughout the Russian Empire:

At the same time, serious observers of the conditions of modern Russis, even among those who sympathise with the aspirations of the Russian people for a form of government which will give some legitimate scope for their ener gies, entertain grave doubts as to the capacity of the Russians for self-government. The mem- bers of the bureaucracy, indeed, base their claim to govern Russia, when they condescend to argue the matter at all; on the ground that acceptance of office the new Minister of the In- no other government is possible. Soon after his

terior made a mendorable declaration." Abroad," said Prince Sviatopolk Mirski, "people speak of a new Constitution for Russia: such a thing is, impossible under present conditions.". It is not only abroad that people speak of a new Constitu tion; it is in Russia itself that the demand is being did not stop short at a repetition of the common made. But Prince Sviatopolk-Mirski's declaration official formula. "But," he continued, "there is such a thing as local self-government, as is exemplified in the Zemstvos. I believe," he added, "in Zematvos." That is a declaration of immense importance coming from such a quarter how important is demonstrated, with singular appositeness in an article on "Self-government in Russia" in the new number of the Empirs Review. For reasons which may readily be sur mised, the writer of the article desires to pre- serve his anonymity; but internal evidence renders almost superfluous the editorial as surance that the writer is entitled to be listened to with respect when he seeks to supplement Prince Sviatopolk-Mirski's state- mont by giving a sketch of the Zemstvo institution in Russia. The evidence which THEOFPTIAN GASETTE IS PRINTED ON PAPER is adduced of the existence of the seeds of a representative system of government throughout the greater part of European

appears to have taken root in Russian provin cial life, the success which has on the whole attended it, and the possibilities which it presents of preparing the people for the difficult. task of self-government. The Zemstvo instita tion is a tiny plant, but if it be wisely tended it may yet grow into a noble tree. A stiff artillery fire was opened on the Russian right at daylight, and lasted for several hours. The fire continued at intervals during the day. The Russians are expecting a general attack. All ranges have been carefully marked, and whichever army attacks is likely to suffer severely.. (Reuter.)

Lord Cromer, in his report on Egypt for1903, had alluded to their publications, which, he said, showed that many of the abuses which until lately existed in Egypt almost in their original form were of very ancient date.. "For instance, plentiful allusions, are made to the system of tax-farming, which it is well known prevailed in Egypt, as elsewhere, from time immemorial, and which appears everywhere to have given sise to abuses very similar in chs- tacter." Lord Cromer then pointed out that with the recent fishery reforms almost the last restige of this iniquitous and oppressive sys- tem would disappear. He noted with some in- terest that in the days of Domitian the system -though without doubt equally oppressive to the taxpayers seemed hardly, to have been so lucrative to the tax-farmers as in those of Abbas II. It was pointed out that the ordinary subscription of a guinea, after payment of the expenses of the publications and the, office dues, only left about three shillings for the purposes of excavation, and an urgent appeal was therefore made to all subscribers to double their sub- scription at least for the current year, or to make a substantial donation, else the small capital of the fund would have to be drawn on. The accounts were adopted without discussion.

Portions of this narrative certainly bear some resemblance to the adventures of Sindbad the Sailor; yet in the main it corresponds well with the records of Junker and Nachtigal, while it contains many details unknown to them. Throughout Zabair appears as what Wingate (1) describes him, a born leader Sir John Evans then delivered his address. of men.
